BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The new snow and wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The fresh wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant above the tree line. On steep slopes and in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large dry slab avalanches are possible. At elevated altitudes the avalanche prone locations are more prevalent.
Medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large dry loose snow avalanches are possible as a consequence of the new snow. In steep terrain there is a danger of falling on the hard snow surface.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: As a consequence of new snow and wind, visible wind slabs formed. Snow depths vary greatly at intermediate and high altitudes, depending on the infuence of the wind. In particular at low and intermediate altitudes only a little snow is now lying.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs and gliding snow require caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of the strong wind, fresh snow drift accumulations will form. These are prone to triggering at elevated altitudes. Caution is to be exercised in particular adjacent to ridgelines in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain above approximately 2200 m. The number and size of avalanche prone locations will increase with altitude. These avalanche prone locations are easy to recognise.

In addition a moderate (level 2) danger of gliding avalanches exists, in particular on steep east, south and west facing slopes below approximately 2600 m. Gliding avalanches can be released at any time of day or night. Caution is to be exercised in areas with glide cracks.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area 5 to 20 cm of snow fell on Sunday above approximately 1000 m. In the Venediger Range up to 30 cm of snow fell on Sunday above approximately 1000 m. The wind will be moderate to strong in some regions. The fresh wind slabs are lying on soft layers at elevated altitudes. The fresh wind slabs can in some cases be released easily.

The new snow is lying on a crust in all aspects below approximately 2600 m. Low and intermediate altitudes: The old snowpack is fairly homogeneous and its surface has a melt-freeze crust that is strong in many cases. This also applies on steep sunny slopes at high altitude.

The old snowpack will be stable over a wide area.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment:
Fresh wind slabs require caution.
A latent danger of gliding avalanches exists.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and wind slabs require caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Above approximately 1800 m snow will fall on Tuesday in particular along the border with France and along the border with Switzerland. The strong wind will transport the new snow significantly.
In the neighbouring regions and at intermediate and high altitudes the danger of dry avalanches will increase gradually to level 3 (considerable) in the afternoon.
The fresh wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in some cases in all aspects above the tree line. They will be deposited on soft layers in particular on north to east to south facing aspects.
The avalanche prone locations for dry avalanches are to be found in particular on very steep slopes and in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. Meticulous route selection is appropriate.
In the morning and where less new snow falls, the danger of falling on hard snow remains, so it is advisable to carry snow knives and crampons for the steeper sections.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Sunday: 10 to 20 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen since the afternoon above approximately 2000 m.
Over a wide area new snow and wind slabs are lying on a hard crust. In some cases the wind slabs have bonded poorly with the old snowpack.
Below approximately 1800 m thus far only a little snow is lying. Snow depths vary greatly at high altitude, depending on the infuence of the wind.
The old snowpack is hard and its surface has a crust.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Wednesday: The avalanche danger will persist.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and wind slabs require caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Above approximately 1800 m snow will fall on Tuesday in particular along the border with France and along the border with Switzerland. The strong wind will transport the new snow significantly.
In the neighbouring regions and at intermediate and high altitudes the danger of dry avalanches will increase gradually to level 3 (considerable) in the afternoon.
The fresh wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in some cases in all aspects above the tree line. They will be deposited on soft layers in particular on north to east to south facing aspects.
The avalanche prone locations for dry avalanches are to be found in particular on very steep slopes and in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. Meticulous route selection is appropriate.
In the morning and where less new snow falls, the danger of falling on hard snow remains, so it is advisable to carry snow knives and crampons for the steeper sections.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Sunday: 10 to 20 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen since the afternoon above approximately 2000 m.
Over a wide area new snow and wind slabs are lying on a hard crust. In some cases the wind slabs have bonded poorly with the old snowpack.
Below approximately 1800 m thus far only a little snow is lying. Snow depths vary greatly at high altitude, depending on the infuence of the wind.
The old snowpack is hard and its surface has a crust.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Wednesday: The avalanche danger will persist.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Fresh wind slabs require caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of snowfall and the strong wind, fresh snow drift accumulations formed. These are in some cases prone to triggering at elevated altitudes. Caution is to be exercised in particular adjacent to ridgelines above approximately 2200 m. These avalanche prone locations are easy to recognise.

In addition a certain danger of gliding avalanches exists. This applies in the regions with a lot of snow on steep east, south and west facing slopes below approximately 2600 m. Caution is to be exercised in areas with glide cracks.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area 10 to 20 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen above approximately 1000 m. The fresh wind slabs are lying on soft layers at elevated altitudes.

Towards its base, the snowpack is faceted. The amount of snow is subject to significant local variations above the tree line.
Low and intermediate altitudes: The snowpack is fairly homogeneous and its surface has a melt-freeze crust that is strong in many cases, this also applies on steep sunny slopes at high altitude.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment:
Fresh wind slabs require caution.
A certain danger of gliding avalanches exists.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The new snow and wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The fresh wind slabs can be released even by a single winter sport participant above the tree line. On steep slopes and in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain small and medium-sized dry slab avalanches are possible. At elevated altitudes the avalanche prone locations are more prevalent.
Mostly small dry loose snow avalanches are possible as a consequence of the new snow.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: As a consequence of new snow and wind, wind slabs will form. Snow depths vary greatly at intermediate and high altitudes, depending on the infuence of the wind. In particular at low and intermediate altitudes a little snow is lying.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Fresh wind slabs require caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of the strong wind, fresh snow drift accumulations will form. These are prone to triggering at elevated altitudes. Caution is to be exercised in particular adjacent to ridgelines in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain above approximately 2200 m. These avalanche prone locations are easy to recognise.

In addition a certain danger of gliding avalanches exists. This applies in the regions with a lot of snow on steep east, south and west facing slopes below approximately 2600 m. Caution is to be exercised in areas with glide cracks.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area 10 to 20 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, fell on Sunday above approximately 1000 m. The wind will be moderate to strong in some regions. The fresh wind slabs are lying on soft layers at elevated altitudes. The fresh wind slabs can in some cases be released easily.

Towards its base, the snowpack is faceted. The amount of snow is subject to significant local variations above the tree line.
Low and intermediate altitudes: The old snowpack is fairly homogeneous and its surface has a melt-freeze crust that is strong in many cases, this also applies on steep sunny slopes at high altitude.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment:
Fresh wind slabs require caution.
A certain danger of gliding avalanches exists.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Since Sunday wind slabs formed in particular in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation as well as at intermediate and high altitudes.
These can be released by a single winter sport participant in isolated cases. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain and at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack.
The older wind slabs are covered with new snow in some cases and therefore difficult to recognise.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Some new snow to low altitudes. In particular at elevated altitudes snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind. Faceted weak layers exist in the snowpack on wind-loaded slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Strong northwesterly wind: The avalanche danger will not decrease for the time being.

BulletinMeasurements.highlights: The new snow and wind slabs are bonding quite well with the old snowpack in all aspects above approximately 2000 m.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow from late morning.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The weather conditions facilitated a gradual strengthening of the snowpack in particular below approximately 2600 m. The fresh snow and the mostly small wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in isolated cases in particular on steep, little used north, northeast and northwest facing slopes above approximately 2500 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The old snowpack will be favourable at intermediate and high altitudes. In particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls as well as at high altitude mostly small wind slabs formed.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The new snow will be deposited on the quite favourable surface of an old snowpack. From a snow sport perspective, in most cases insufficient snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: As the day progresses, a few moist snow slides are possible. The new snow is lying on the favourable surface of an old snowpack. The fresh wind slabs can only be released by large loads in most cases.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: As a consequence of new snow and wind, mostly small wind slabs will form. Snow depths vary greatly at intermediate and high altitudes, depending on the infuence of the wind. In particular at low and intermediate altitudes a little snow is lying.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The new snow and wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The fresh wind slabs can be released even by a single winter sport participant above the tree line. On steep slopes and in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain small and medium-sized dry slab avalanches are possible. At elevated altitudes the avalanche prone locations are more prevalent.
Small and medium-sized dry loose snow avalanches are possible as a consequence of the new snow. In steep terrain there is a danger of falling on the hard snow surface.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: As a consequence of new snow and wind, wind slabs will form. Snow depths vary greatly at intermediate and high altitudes, depending on the infuence of the wind. In particular at low and intermediate altitudes a little snow is lying.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights:
Some snow will fall on Tuesday. The wind will be strong.
There is a danger of falling on the icy crust.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The new snow and wind slabs are lying on a crust in all aspects. In some localities mostly small wind slabs will form. The danger of dry avalanches will increase during the day, reaching danger level 2 (moderate).
The greatest danger remains slipping on hard snow, so it is advisable to carry snow knives and crampons for the steepest sections.
Fresh wind slabs can be released in isolated cases at their margins. Especially transitions into gullies and bowls places that are protected from the wind, in particular on very steep slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Sunday: 5 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen since the afternoon above approximately 2000 m. Over a wide area new snow and wind slabs are lying on a hard crust.
Snow depths vary greatly at high altitude, depending on the infuence of the wind. In some cases the wind slabs have bonded poorly with the old snowpack.
Especially on steep sunny slopes only a little snow is lying. Also adjacent to ridgelines hardly any snow is lying.
As a consequence of the strong to storm force wind, a crust formed on the surface. This applies above approximately 2600 m.
In its middle, the snowpack is fairly homogeneous and its surface has a melt-freeze crust that is strong in many cases. This applies below approximately 2600 m.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Wednesday: The avalanche danger will persist.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights:
Some snow will fall on Tuesday. The wind will be strong.
There is a danger of falling on the icy crust.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The new snow and wind slabs are lying on a crust in all aspects. In some localities mostly small wind slabs will form. The danger of dry avalanches will increase during the day, reaching danger level 2 (moderate).
The greatest danger remains slipping on hard snow, so it is advisable to carry snow knives and crampons for the steepest sections.
Fresh wind slabs can be released in isolated cases at their margins. Especially transitions into gullies and bowls places that are protected from the wind, in particular on very steep slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Sunday: 5 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen since the afternoon above approximately 2000 m. Over a wide area new snow and wind slabs are lying on a hard crust.
Snow depths vary greatly at high altitude, depending on the infuence of the wind. In some cases the wind slabs have bonded poorly with the old snowpack.
Especially on steep sunny slopes only a little snow is lying. Also adjacent to ridgelines hardly any snow is lying.
As a consequence of the strong to storm force wind, a crust formed on the surface. This applies above approximately 2600 m.
In its middle, the snowpack is fairly homogeneous and its surface has a melt-freeze crust that is strong in many cases. This applies below approximately 2600 m.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Wednesday: The avalanche danger will persist.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The new snow will be deposited on the favourable surface of an old snowpack in all aspects.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The danger exists in particular in alpine snow sports terrain.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: New snow is lying on a hard crust.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Restraint should be exercised because avalanches can sweep people along and give rise to falls.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Some snow fell on Sunday. Since Sunday the wind has been moderate to strong. In some localities small wind slabs formed. The more recent wind slabs are to be found especially in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain.
Wind slabs are lying on a hard crust. There is a danger of falling on the hard snow surface.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The new snow is lying on a crust. In particular at elevated altitudes snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind.
At low and intermediate altitudes only a little snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Strong northwesterly wind: The avalanche danger will persist.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and weakly bonded old snow require caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: In all regions only a little snow is lying. The avalanche danger will increase a little during the day. Mostly the avalanches are small.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The snowpack will be quite stable. Snow depths vary greatly above the tree line, depending on the infuence of the wind. Over a wide area up to 15 cm of snow has fallen above approximately 1500 m.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: From a snow sport perspective, in most cases insufficient snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: As the day progresses, individual moist snow slides are possible. The new snow is lying on the favourable surface of an old snowpack. The fresh wind slabs can be released in isolated cases.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The wind slabs are to be found in particular in the vicinity of peaks. The snowpack will be subject to considerable local variations. In particular at low and intermediate altitudes a little snow is lying.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The conditions are generally favourable. Fresh wind slabs.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
In some places small wind slabs formed. The fresh wind slabs can be released in isolated cases on steep shady slopes in high Alpine regions. The avalanche prone locations are rare and are easy to recognise.
In steep terrain there is a danger of falling on the hard snow surface.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
In some regions up to 10 cm of snow has fallen above approximately 1000 m. The strong wind has transported the new snow. The old snowpack will be stable over a wide area.

Low and intermediate altitudes: The snowpack is wet all the way through and its surface has a melt-freeze crust that is strong in many cases.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: In all aspects a little snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
In these regions from a snow sport perspective, insufficient snow is lying.
Even in moderately steep terrain there is a danger of falling on the icy crust.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Hardly any snow is lying at intermediate and high altitudes. The snowpack is stable and its surface has a resilient crust.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: In all aspects in all altitude zones thus far only a little snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The avalanche prone locations are rather rare. These avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular above approximately 2400 m.
Restraint should be exercised because avalanches can sweep people along and give rise to falls.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Below approximately 2400 m from a snow sport perspective, in most cases insufficient snow is lying. At higher altitudes snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind.
